meanings.definition: To make a signal or gesture to communicate something
meanings.sent1: She would signalise to her friend across the room with a wave.
meanings.sent2: The traffic officer used hand signals to signalise the drivers to stop.
meanings.sent3: During the game of charades, he tried to signalise 'elephant' but ended up looking like a monkey.
meanings.sent4: The flickering lights on the dashboard seemed to signalise an impending car breakdown.
meanings.sent5: The lighthouse on the cliff would signalise ships of the dangerous rocks ahead.

meanings.definition: To distinguish or highlight something as important or significant
meanings.sent1: The red carpet was used to signalise the importance of the event.
meanings.sent2: Her bright smile would always signalise her presence in a room.
meanings.sent3: The oversized hat she wore seemed to signalise her as the quirky one in the group.
meanings.sent4: The old clock in the hallway seemed to signalise the passage of time with each tick.
meanings.sent5: The rare flower in the garden seemed to signalise the beauty of nature in full bloom.
